utils

Class DataMgr

  • java.lang.Object
    • utils.DataMgr

  • public class DataMgr
extends java.lang.Object
    The class acts as an I/O Manager class for saving and loading data for complex objects in the library such as Graph, HGraph, and properties HashMap objects. The class is thread-safe (reentrant).

    Notes:

    • 2019-02-08: changed the signature of method readVectorsFromFileInRange() to return List objects so as to avoid penalties related to the old Vector class.
    • 2020-04-13: expanded method readPropsFromFile() to allow loading array and matrix/sparse-matrix objects into the props hash-map to be returned.
    • 2020-04-22: expanded same method as above to allow storing keys with null values. Also modified slightly code dealing with setting debug levels when reading props.
    • 2020-07-22: added functionality to convert the columns of a dataset to have zero mean and standard deviation one.
    • 2020-07-24: added functionality to write a double array to a text file.
    • 2020-08-07: added functionality to convert the columns of a dataset to shift their mean and variance in accordance to some other dataset's mean and variance.
    • 2020-10-02: added functionality to convert the columns of a dataset so that every cell is divided according to the max and min values of some other dataset's min and max values (needed when normalization occurs so that the values are shrank to the interval [-1,+1].)

    Title: popt4jlib

    Description: A Parallel Meta-Heuristic Optimization Library in Java

    Copyright: Copyright (c) 2011-2020

    Company:

    Version:
    2.1
    Author:
    Ioannis T. Christou

      • readPropsFromFile

        public static java.util.HashMap readPropsFromFile(java.lang.String filename)
                                           throws java.io.IOException
        Reads properties from the given file and stores them as <key,value> pairs in the returned HashMap. Unless the key string is a special keyword (see below), the value is assumed first to be an int value, and if value does not represent an int it is then assumed to be a long value; if value does not represent a long it is then assumed to be a double value; if value does not represent a double either, value is assumed to be representing a boolean value (the strings "true" or "false" in all lower- or upper-case letters); if this also fails, value is kept in the hash-table as-is, that is, as a String type.

        In case key is the keyword "graph", the key value is the next token in the line, and the full filename of the file containing the graph to be constructed using the method readGraphFromFile2(String) is the next token.

        In case key is the keyword "class", the key value is the next token in the line, and the object to be constructed together with its string arguments is given in the rest of the line. However, if the line is of the form "class,mitsos,null" then the key "mitsos" is stored in props along with null object value. This allows for null values to be stored in the table for various keys.

        In case key is the keyword "ref", the key value is the next token in the line, and the next (and last) token in the line must be the name of an existing key in the properties defined so far, the value of which is also stored in props under the new key provided in this line.

        In case key is the keyword "array", the key value is the next token in the line, the next token is the type of the array ("int","long","double", "boolean","string" or the full class name of the type of the objects in the array) and the rest of the tokens are either the values of the primitive types defined, or else each token must simply specify the name of one of the keys that are already encountered (higher up in the props file) and stored in the hash-table to be returned (and of course they must be of the right type). The order in which the values appear defines the order of elements in the array value object to be stored along with the key name. Notice that when the array is supposed to hold as elements other arrays, then the type of the array must be the canonical type name for arrays, e.g. "[Lpopt4jlib.DblArray1Vector;" etc. Notice the "[L" in the beginning of the full class name the ";" in the end, which is used to indicate array-of in Java. HOWEVER, to declare that the elements of the array are themselves arrays of a primitive type, use the name of the primitive type followed by square brackets, e.g. "int[]" or "double[]". Also notice that when the type of the elements is any non-primitive type (except "String"), the resulting object stored in the return hash-map is of type Object[].

        In case key is the keyword "arrayofcopies", the key value is the next token in the line; the next token is the number of copies, and the next one is the full class-name of the object whose copies shall be stored in the array, followed by the argument values, in the same manner as in the lines starting with the keyword "class". This is a convenient short-cut so that arrays of identically constructed (but different) objects can be stored in an array. The array is stored with type Object[].

        In case key is the keyword "dblarray", then the value is the name of the property, and the next token is the filename of a text file describing the array of doubles to be read via the method readDoubleLabelsFromFile(filename). The resulting value object stored in the returned hash-map is of type double[].

        Similarly as above, when the key is the keyword "intarray" (now it is the readIntegerLabelsFromFile(filename) that does the work.)

        In case key is the keyword "matrix", then the value is the name of the property, and the next token is the filename of a text file describing the matrix to be read via the method readMatrixFromFile(filename). The resulting value object stored in the returned hash-map is of type double[][].

        In case key is the keyword "matrix01" then things work as above, but now the cells of the matrix are all in [0,1] by subtracting from each cell the column minimum and dividing the difference by the difference of the column max minus the column min.

        In case key is the keyword "matrix-1_1" then things work as above, but now the cells of the matrix are all in [-1,1].

        In case key is the keyword "matrixN01" then things work as above but now the columns of the matrix have zero mean and unit standard deviation.

        In case key is the keyword "matrixN01o" then the columns of the matrix are shifted by the mean and variance found in the matrix described in the file whose name is described last in the same line; this means that in such a line, there must be 2 specified filenames, first the required one, then the file containing the data for which we require their mean and variance.

        In case key is the keyword "matrix-1_1o" then the columns of the matrix are transformed by first subtracting from each cell the column minimum of the matrix described in the file whose name is described last in the same line (as above), and then dividing the difference by the difference of the other matrix column max minus column min. The result does NOT have to be that all cells are in [-1,1] (but should be close.)

        In case key is the keyword "sparsematrix", the the value is the name of the property, and the next token is the filename of a text file describing the matrix to be read via the method readSparseVectorsFromFile and the resulting object stored as a value in the returned hash-map is a java.util.Vector<DblArray1SparseVector> object.

        In case key is the keyword "rndgen", the RndUtil class's seed is populated with the value of this line (long int). The seed does not need to be stored in the HashMap returned. Also, if a 3rd argument is provided, it indicates the number of distinct threads to require access to RndUtil, and thus it sets the required extra instances of Random objects needed.

        In case key is the keyword "dbglvl", the method utils.Messenger.getInstance(classname).setDebugLevel(lvl) is invoked where the value of the string classname is the next comma separated value in the line, and the lvl value is the value after that in the same line. If the classname is omitted in the line, the value "default" is assumed.

        In case key is the keyword "dbgclasses" then value is assumed to be an integer, and the method utils.Debug.setDebugBit(val) is called with the value represented by the value string.

        In case key is the keyword "mpc.maxsize", the parallel.MsgPassingCoordinator class's max data size is set to the value of this line (int), via a call to MsgPassingCoordinator.setMaxSize(val).

        In case key is the keyword "rpp.poolsize", the parallel.RegisteredParcelPool class's pool size is set to the value of this line (int), via a call to RegisteredParcelThreadLocalPools.setPoolSize(val).

        File format is: 

         key,value[,classname|graphfilename][,opts]
 [...]
        .

        Empty lines and lines starting with # are ignored.

        Parameters:
        filename - String
        Returns:
        HashMap
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • readVectorsFromFile

        public static java.util.Vector readVectorsFromFile(java.lang.String filename)
                                            throws java.io.IOException
        reads the vectors from a file of the form 
         [
 numdocs totaldimensions
 dim,val [ dim,val]*
 [...]
 ]
        dim is in [1...totaldimensions] the documents are represented as a vector representation of a vector in a vector space of dimension totaldimensions. If a <dim,val> pair does not appear for a vector, the value for this coordinate is assumed zero.
        Parameters:
        filename - String
        Returns:
        Vector // Vector<VectorIntf>
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • readVectorsFromFileInRange

        public static java.util.List readVectorsFromFileInRange(java.lang.String filename,
                                                        int fromIndex,
                                                        int toIndex)
                                                 throws java.io.IOException,
                                                        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException,
                                                        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException
        same functionality as in readVectorsFromFile(String) method, except that it only reads and returns the vectors in the lines in the range [fromIndex, toIndex] (fromIndex and toIndex take values in {0,...,readNumVectorsInFile(String)-1}).
        Parameters:
        filename - String
        fromIndex - int
        toIndex - int
        Returns:
        List // ArrayList<DblArray1Vector>
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if fromIndex > toIndex or any of the 2 is outside the valid range of indices.
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if fromIndex or toIndex are out of range.

      • readSparseVectorsFromFile

        public static java.util.Vector readSparseVectorsFromFile(java.lang.String filename)
                                                  throws java.io.IOException
        reads the vectors from a file of the form 
         numdocs totaldimensions
 dim,val [dim,val]
 [...]
        dim is in [1...totaldimensions] the documents are represented as a sparse vector representation of a vector in a vector space of dimension totaldimensions. Notice that the sparse vectors have as default value, zero.
        Parameters:
        filename - String
        Returns:
        Vector // Vector<DblArray1SparseVector>
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • readIntSparseVectorsFromFile

        public static java.util.Vector readIntSparseVectorsFromFile(java.lang.String filename)
                                                     throws java.io.IOException
        reads int-valued vectors from a file of the form 
         numdocs totaldimensions
 dim,val [dim,val]
 [...]
        dim is in [1...totaldimensions], val must always be integer the documents are represented as a sparse vector representation of a vector in a vector space of dimension totaldimensions.
        Parameters:
        filename - String
        Returns:
        Vector // Vector<IntArray1SparseVector>
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • readSparseVectorsFEFromFile

        public static java.util.Vector readSparseVectorsFEFromFile(java.lang.String filename)
                                                    throws java.io.IOException
        reads the vectors from a file of the form 
         numdocs totaldimensions
 dim,val [dim,val]
 [...]
        dim is in [1...totaldimensions] the documents are represented using full storage requirements (as a normal double[]) taking up a lot of space, but also maintaining an index of the non-zero positions for very fast getQuick(i) and getIthNonnZeroPos(i) operations.
        Parameters:
        filename - String
        Returns:
        Vector // Vector<DblArray1SparseVectorFE>
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • readGraphFromFile

        public static Graph readGraphFromFile(java.lang.String filename)
                               throws java.io.IOException,
                                      GraphException
        filename format is of the form: 
         numnodes numarcs
 starta enda [weighta]
 [...]
        . The starta, enda are in [0...num_nodes-1] weighta is double (non-negative)
        Parameters:
        filename - String
        Returns:
        Graph
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException
        GraphException

 starta enda [weighta]
 [...]
 [weight_node1...]
        . The starta, enda are in [1...num_nodes] weighta is double (non-negative) node weights after arcs listing, if they exist, are double (non-negative)

      • readHGraphFromhMeTiSFile

        public static HGraph readHGraphFromhMeTiSFile(java.lang.String filename)
                                       throws java.io.IOException,
                                              GraphException
        filename format is of the form: 
         numarcs numnodes [1]
 [weighta] node1 node2 ... nodek
 [...]
        The nodei are in [1...numnodes] weighta is int (non-negative). If it does not exist (the third value in the first line does not exist), then its value is 1.
        Parameters:
        filename - String
        Returns:
        HGraph
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException
        GraphException

      • writeGraphToFile

        public static void writeGraphToFile(Graph g,
                                    java.lang.String filename)
                             throws java.io.IOException
        takes as input an already constructed graph, and prints it in MeTiS format in the file specified in the second argument. The format of this output file is as follows: 
         numnodes numarcs
 starta enda weight
 ...
        starta, enda are in [0,...,numnodes-1]
        Parameters:
        g - Graph
        filename - String
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • writeGraphToFile2

        public static void writeGraphToFile2(Graph g,
                                     java.lang.String filename)
                              throws java.io.IOException
        takes as input an already constructed graph, and prints it in MeTiS format in the file specified in the second argument. The format of this output file is as follows: 
         numarcs numnodes
 ...
 starta enda weight
 ...
 nodeweight
 ...
        starta, enda are in [1,...,numnodes] nodeweight are double values, the first corresponds to the 1st node etc.
        Parameters:
        g - Graph
        filename - String
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • writeGraphToHGRFile

        public static void writeGraphToHGRFile(Graph g,
                                       java.lang.String filename)
                                throws java.io.IOException
        takes as input an already constructed graph, and prints it in HMeTiS format in the file specified in the second argument. The format of this output file is specified in the comments for method writeClusterEnsembleToHGRFile()
        Parameters:
        g - Graph
        filename - String
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • writeGraphToGRFile

        public static void writeGraphToGRFile(Graph g,
                                      java.lang.String filename)
                               throws java.io.IOException
        takes as input an already constructed graph, and prints it in MeTiS format in the file specified in the second argument. The format of this output file is as follows: 
         numnodes numarcs 1
 ...
 nbor_id1 edgeweight_1 nbor_id2 edgeweight_2 ...
        Parameters:
        g - Graph
        filename - String
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • writeVectorsToFile

                                      int tot_dims,
                                      java.lang.String filename)
                               throws java.io.IOException
        writes the vectors in the 1st argument to file specified in 3rd arg. according to the format specified in readVectorsFromFile().
        Parameters:
        docs - Vector // Vector<VectorIntf>
        tot_dims - int
        filename - String
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • writeSparseVectorsToFile

        public static void writeSparseVectorsToFile(java.util.Vector docs,
                                            int tot_dims,
                                            java.lang.String filename)
                                     throws java.io.IOException
        writes the sparse vectors in the 1st argument to file specified in 3rd argument according to the format specified in readSparseVectorsFromFile(). Notice: it takes care of the case where the vectors are IntArray1SparseVector objects, and it also takes care of the case where the default value of the sparse objects is non-zero.
        Parameters:
        docs - Vector // Vector<SparseVectorIntf>
        tot_dims - int
        filename - String
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException
